title: Dietary Supplement Fact Sheets
cleaned_text: This collection of fact sheets and other resources from the NIH Office of Dietary Supplements and other federal government sources presents information about dietary supplements and their ingredients. These include vitamins, minerals, herbs and botanicals, probiotics, and more. Many of these resources are available in versions written for consumers (in both English and Spanish) and also for health and Integrative Health (NCCIH) [Acai Berry](https://nccih.nih.gov/health/acai) - Source: National Health (NCCIH) Common vera](#AloeVera) [Aloe Vera](https://nccih.nih.gov/health/aloevera) - Source: Health (NCCIH) [Aloe Vera](http://www.niehs.nih.gov/health/materials/aloe_vera_508.pdf) - Source: National Institute of Environmental Health Sciences (NIEHS) Common names: aloe vera, aloe, burn plant, lily of the desert, elephant's gall Latin names: Aloe vera, Integrative Health (NCCIH) Common names: astragalus, bei qi, names: Astragalus membranaceus, Astragalus mongholicus [Exercise and Athletic Performance](#)) [Vitamin A](#VitaminA) Rich sources of vitamin A include green leafy, orange, and yellow vegetables such as carrots and spinach. B [Bacopa monnieri](#BacopaMonnieri) - BCAAs (branched-chain pollen](https://medlineplus.gov/druginfo/natural/78.html) U.S. of Medicine - Beetroot (beet juice) (see [Exercise and Athletic Performance](#)) [Berberine](#Berberine) [Berberine](https://medlineplus.gov/druginfo/natural/1126.html) - Source: MedlinePlus, U.S. National Library of - Beta-alanine (see [Exercise and Athletic Performance](#)) Athletic Performance](#)) [Bilberry](#Bilberry) [Bilberry](https://nccih.nih.gov/health/bilberry) Source: is naturally present in some such as salmon and eggs. [Bitter melon](#BitterMelon) [Bitter Melon](https://medlineplus.gov/druginfo/natural/795.html) - Source: Medicine [Bitter orange](#BitterOrange) Common names: bitter orange, Seville orange, sour orange, zhi shi Latin Library of Medicine [Boron](#Boron) Apples are a good source of boron. [Botanical Dietary Supplements](#BotanicalDietarySupplements) [Brain health ](#BrainHealth) - Athletic Performance](#)) [Bromelain](#Bromelain) [Bromelain](https://nccih.nih.gov/health/bromelain) - Source: National Complementary and Integrative Health (NCCIH) Common names: bromelain, pineapple comosus L. [Butterbur](#Butterbur) [Butterbur](https://nccih.nih.gov/health/butterbur) - Source: Common names: butterbur, petasites and purple butterbur. Butterbur is also known under several patented standardized extract forms, such as Petadolex. Latin names: Petasites [Thiamin](#)) [Vitamin B12](#VitaminB12) Foods from animals, but not plants, naturally have vitamin B12. - Vitamin B2 (see [Riboflavin](#)) - Vitamin B3 acid](#)) [Vitamin B6](#VitaminB6) Vitamin B6 is found naturally in many foods and is added to others. - Vitamin B7 (see [Biotin](#)) - Vitamin B9 (see [Folate](#)) C [Caffeine](#CaffeineForPerformance) [Calcium](#Calcium) Calcium-rich foods include milk, cheese, and yogurt; vegetables like kale, broccoli, and Chinese cabbage; and canned sardines and salmon with soft bones that you eat. [Calendula](#Calendula) [Calendula](https://medlineplus.gov/druginfo/natural/235.html) - Source: MedlinePlus, U.S. National [Weight Loss](#)) [Capsaicinoids](#Capsaicinoids) [Capsicum](#Capsicum) [Carnitine](#Carnitine) Animal products such as meat, fish, poultry, and milk are the best sources of carnitine. [Chamomile (Roman)](#ChamomileRoman) [Chasteberry](#Chasteberry) [Chasteberry](https://nccih.nih.gov/health/chasteberry) (NCCIH) - Chitosan (see [Weight Loss](#)) [Choline](#Choline) You can get recommended amounts of choline by eating a variety of foods. [Chondroitin](#Chondroitin) Chondroitin is found in cartilage, the connective tissue that helps cushion the joints. [Chromium](#Chromium) Chromium is a mineral found in many foods. [Cinnamon](#Cinnamon) [Cinnamon](https://nccih.nih.gov/health/cinnamon) - Source: National Center for Complementary and Integrative - [Clove](https://medlineplus.gov/druginfo/natural/251.html) Source: Library of Medicine [Coenzyme Q10](#CoenzymeQ10) - (kola source of copper. [COVID-19](#COVID19) [Cranberry](#Cranberry) [Cranberry](https://nccih.nih.gov/health/cranberry) - Source: National macrocarpon) [Creatine](#Creatine) [Vitamin C](#VitaminC) You can get enough vitamin C by eating a variety of foods including citrus fruits (such as oranges and grapefruit) and their juices, as well as red and green pepper, kiwifruit, broccoli, strawberries, baked potatoes, and tomatoes. E [Echinacea](#Echinacea) [Echinacea](https://nccih.nih.gov/health/echinacea) - Source: National Center for Complementary and Integrative (and Medicine [Energy drinks](#EnergyDrinks) "Energy" drinks are marketed as promoting alertness, concentration, energy, weight loss, athletic performance, or stamina. [Ephedra](#Ephedra) [Essiac/Flor-Essence](#EssiacFlorEssence) [Eucalyptus](#Eucalyptus) [Eucalyptus](https://medlineplus.gov/druginfo/natural/700.html) - (Oenothera biennis) [Exercise and Athletic Performance](#ExerciseAndAthleticPerformance) Some dietary supplement ingredients are claimed to enhance exercise and athletic performance. [Eye conditions](#EyeConditions) [Eye conditions](https://www.nccih.nih.gov/health/eye-conditions-at-a-glance) - Source: National Center for Complementary and Integrative Health [Vitamin E](#VitaminE) Many foods have vitamin E including vegetable oils (such as wheat germ, sunflower, and safflower oils), nuts (such as almonds), seeds (such as sunflower seeds), and green vegetables (such as spinach and broccoli). F [Fenugreek](#Fenugreek) [Fenugreek](https://nccih.nih.gov/health/fenugreek) - Source: National Center Fenugreek (Trigonella foenum-graecum) [Feverfew](#Feverfew) [Feverfew](https://nccih.nih.gov/health/feverfew) acid is added to many grain-based products. - (see (NCCIH) Kava (Piper methysticum) [Weight Loss](#)) [Vitamin K](#VitaminK) Green leafy vegetables are good sources of vitamin K. N - N-acetylcysteine (NAC) (see [COVID-19](#)) [Niacin](#Niacin) Niacin is important for the development and function of cells in your body. [Nitric oxide ](#NitricOxide) [Noni](#Noni) [Noni](https://nccih.nih.gov/health/noni) - Source: [Vitamin A](#VitaminA) Rich sources of vitamin A include green leafy, orange, and yellow vegetables such as carrots and spinach. - Vitamin B1 (see [Thiamin](#)) [Vitamin B12](#VitaminB12) Foods from animals, but not plants, naturally have vitamin B12. - Vitamin B2 (see [Riboflavin](#)) - Vitamin B3 acid](#)) [Vitamin B6](#VitaminB6) Vitamin B6 is found naturally in many foods and is added to others. - Vitamin B7 (see [Biotin](#)) - Vitamin B9 (see [Folate](#)) [Vitamin C](#VitaminC) You can get enough vitamin C by eating a variety of foods including citrus fruits (such as oranges and grapefruit) and their juices, as well as red and green pepper, kiwifruit, broccoli, strawberries, baked potatoes, and tomatoes. [Vitamin D](#VitaminD) Very few foods naturally have vitamin D. Fatty fish such as salmon, tuna, and mackerel are among the best sources. Fortified foods like milk provide most of the vitamin D in American diets. [Vitamin E](#VitaminE) Many foods have vitamin E including vegetable oils (such as wheat germ, sunflower, and safflower oils), nuts (such as almonds), seeds (such as sunflower seeds), and green vegetables (such as spinach and broccoli). [Vitamin K](#VitaminK) Green leafy vegetables are good sources of vitamin K. Z [Zinc](#Zinc) Many foods have zinc. Red meat, poultry, oysters and other seafood, and fortified breakfast cereals are good sources. Beans, nuts, whole grains, and dairy products have some zinc as well.
